text: <@U02F8TTPU> can I get a couple minutes of your time this morning to talk through a sanity check on some new stuff immersion is talking about
yes it is related to that message
oops, my bad for not noticing in the message yesterday that was an open question to be answered
oh nah
totally my miss
I think it'll be essentially painless to add animated gifs, but I'll run a quick check (to see if they perform horribly or some other tizen-specific quirk)
cool. thats basically my question!
the question has been answered: yes, animated gifs look fine on the gear S watch. Example is on the black watch (with white USB dock) under Index->Stickers
Nice! That's great news. Is that how you'd suggest we implement other animations? (Like the etching animation they'll provide, and the watch face animations we'd create?)
watch faces can be done with JS and Canvas, design is the main challenge there (Tizen has 2 example watch face apps, one of which is adapted for the current CES demo)
I haven't seen the etching animation, but it can either be done with frames (PNGs and JS) or jQuery/CSS property animations

I didn't have time to explore it in this project, but Gaston mentioned Velocity.js, which is a drop-in replacement for (slow) jQuery animations, might be worth trying if there's a need for multi-choreographed animated objects and the Gear S webkit browser seems to bog down on them.

Excellent. If we expect it to function well, let's assume that we'll implement anything immersion provides as frame animations. Then we can explore the best options for clock movement as we move forward.
Thank you Marissa!
